WHEAT SEEDED WITH THE LISTER DRILL, A NEW AND PROMISING METHOD . (Courtesy Dempster Mill Mfg. Co., Beatrice, Nebr.) .(1) Seeding wheat with a lister type lurow wheat seeding machine. (2) Snow fills the furrows (left) and protects the wheat from low temperatures and improves the moisture conditions (3) Cracks appear only on the ridges (left) leaving wheat roots un - injured m the furrows. Harrowing checks damage from blow - . ing, increases absorption of moisture and prevents evaporation. (4) Furrow seeded field (left) and surface seeded wheat (right). (5) Furow seeded wheat outyielded the surface seeded wheat 3.3 bushels averaging 27.75 bushels. A more marked difference would be expected m a dry unfavorable year. 31

Status of Work, Jan. 1, 1028 ~ — i i i I **" *"* I**** 1 rHdCKSESL " jib: Lg2^^E^E^!?s3E3sylr?iJi4" f*H ,"*"i Ml '" > . .Status of Work, Jan. 1, 1020 On January 1, 1925, 10 of Nebraska's 93 counties were under supervision for tuberculosis eradication hut none had been declared disease-free areas. Those 10 counties contained 8.9 7c of the cattle and 11.4% of the hog popula - tions of the state. Four years later, on January 1, 1929, there were 43 coun - ties under State and Federal supervision. These counties have hog and cattle populations of 2.744.014 and 1.163,016 head respectively, or 56.1 % of the hogs and 42.17 c of the cattle m the state are now m areas under supervision. Thirty-one of the counties have been declared disease-free territory. These counties contain 1.924.275 hoffs and 807,441 cattle; 39.3% and 29.2% of the hogs and cattle m the state on January 1 this year. Farmers m these 31 coun - ties are entitled to the 10c per cwt. premium which packers pay for hogs raised m tuberculosis-free territory. A decrease of two-thirds m the number of cattle showing lesions of tuber - cu\osis at Omaha slaughter houses from 1917 to -1927 and the condemnation of only one-fourth as many hogs m 192" as m 1922 leaves no doubt as to the efficacy of the program of tuberculosis eradition now m progress. 130
